title: Linc Energy defends gas pollution claims
text:
Tue, Aug 11, 2015, 5:32 PM AEST - Australia Markets closed Linc Energy defends gas pollution claims AAP – 4 minutes 49 seconds ago Recommend Print 
Linc Energy is continuing to defend a controversial underground gas operation against claims of serious pollution thought to have landed four Queensland government workers in hospital. 
The workers fell ill with suspected gas poisoning after conducting soil and gas testing at the Hopeland site, west of Brisbane, in March. 
One said he felt nauseous for several hours and blood tests showed elevated levels of carbon monoxide, according to documents obtained by the ABC. 
Gases released at the plant have also caused the permanent acidification of nearby soil, an expert study commissioned by the state government found. 
While the workers' symptoms were consistent with carbon monoxide exposure, Linc Energy maintains there is no evidence to suggest their sickness was a result of atmospheric contaminants. 
The company organised its own independent inquiry after the incident. 
"The sample that was being collected, from the area where the work parties were working, was found to have no presence of carbon monoxide," a spokesman said. 
Two Linc staff who attended the site did not report any health problems. 
Environment Minister Steven Miles flew to Chinchilla in June with concerns for the wellbeing of 50 families who live near the plant. 
The Environment Department had found enough evidence, after a four-month investigation, to level a fifth charge of causing serious environmental harm against Linc Energy - meaning it could be fined up to $32.5 million. 
The government's report will not be released to local residents until next month. 
Hopeland Community Sustainability Group's Shay Dougall said residents are disgusted. 
"We're told the government investigators became sick, but what about the land holders who have lived with this toxic mix constantly?" she said. 
There is no immediate threat to human health in the area, the department said in a statement. 
"The full extent of any impacts to agriculture, including grazing or cropping, are continuing to be investigated by the department's experts and the University of Queensland," it read. 
Queensland Greens senator Larissa Waters said residents are being used as "test bunnies". 
"It's time to end this toxic experiment with our land, water and people's health that is underground coal gasification and coal seam gas mining alike," she said.
